snippet.textDisplay: I think the only thing they need is to make their cars more reliable than the rest.
snippet.textOriginal: I think the only thing they need is to make their cars more reliable than the rest.

snippet.textDisplay: I had a 2008 760Li, the flagship of BMW . I bought it used in 2013 with 41000 miles on it. This model was introduced in 2002 as 2003 model. In six years BMW had ample opportunity to get the bugs out. I had so many issues with that car and most of them component failures. Three months ago I took it to the BMW service center and told them the car was idling rough. They changed many parts and the bill was $2100 and they could not fix the problem. They were guessing that it was the fuel pump which was priced at $4000 installed. This particular dealer has a huge turnover in their mechanic's roster. There is no one who knows how to fix anything. They just change parts. Making long story short, I sold that car for $5000 with 80800 miles on it. When new it was $136500. I called the BMW north America headquarters and got no help. I have been a BMW customer for 31 years.
snippet.textOriginal: I had a 2008 760Li, the flagship of BMW . I bought it used in 2013 with 41000 miles on it. This model was introduced in 2002 as 2003 model. In six years BMW had ample opportunity to get the bugs out. I had so many issues with that car and most of them component failures. Three months ago I took it to the BMW service center and told them the car was idling rough. They changed many parts and the bill was $2100 and they could not fix the problem. They were guessing that it was the fuel pump which was priced at $4000 installed. This particular dealer has a huge turnover in their mechanic's roster. There is no one who knows how to fix anything. They just change parts. Making long story short, I sold that car for $5000 with 80800 miles on it. When new it was $136500. I called the BMW north America headquarters and got no help. I have been a BMW customer for 31 years.

snippet.textDisplay:
Used to be
BMW- Sporty
Mercedes- Luxury
Audi- Tactile Function

Now Audi and Mercedes have worked hard to do all 3, while BMW is doing none of the 3 better than the rest. (Aside from speciality performance line up, 2/3/4 M series)

Stagnant is the exact word. Rather than refining and harking back to their heritage, they are busy making more giant squeezed turd styled $200 (4 door?) COUPES offering nothing unique or better than the competition. Come on guys...

snippet.textDisplay:
Perhaps what you are saying about BMW could have merit, but they are putting much of their R&D efforts these days in electric vehicles. Luxury is a way of making money, perhaps they would prefer to make money being green.
Now if you wanted to compare the offerings of BMW's to the world, with what America (or even Canada) offers us, there is no contest is there really? One maker produces a precision instrument, the other a club-like and unsophisticated instrument to appeal to the teenage delinquent mind of Americans.
snippet.textOriginal:
Perhaps what you are saying about BMW could have merit, but they are putting much of their R&D efforts these days in electric vehicles. Luxury is a way of making money, perhaps they would prefer to make money being green.

One maker produces a precision instrument, the other a club-like and unsophisticated instrument to appeal to the teenage delinquent mind of Americans.

snippet.textDisplay:
When they started putting ///M badges on basically everything with the e39 540i being an exception, thats when the brand went down hill. But more to the point there is no such thing as a "drivers car" anymore. The consumer base is nothing like it was in the 80's 90's and early 2000s and those are the last of the buyers who truly want drivers cars. Cars are just a status symbol now and people just want cheaply built junk to whoa their friends with while parking the car on the street to get dinged, scratched & dented just to get a new one to replace it with in a year or two. But it's all good as long as it has usb ports & cup holders for overpriced coffee. Brands like kia, Hyundai and genesis will do very well in the years to come and bmw, audi and mercedes sales will decline. Its up to them to turn that around but that's not easy when nobody cares about quality anymore. Now its all about the lowest mothly payment with the biggest "wow" factor.
P.s i buy cheap cars that are fun to drive that i can fix myself because i could care less about impressing people who don't pay my bills.

snippet.textDisplay: I worked at a BMW. I was driving a customer's car when the power steering line broke beneath me, leaked power steering fluid everywhere, and I proceeded to pull up the vehicle with brute strength turning the wheel (x3 or x5 from ~2013). Literally we were about to send her on her way. The cars leak and the engines don't last, but hey, spend $60k msrp on an i3 and have it devalued to $12k on the used market. The 2020 8 series M isn't half bad though
snippet.textOriginal: I worked at a BMW. I was driving a customer's car when the power steering line broke beneath me, leaked power steering fluid everywhere, and I proceeded to pull up the vehicle with brute strength turning the wheel (x3 or x5 from ~2013). Literally we were about to send her on her way. The cars leak and the engines don't last, but hey, spend $60k msrp on an i3 and have it devalued to $12k on the used market. The 2020 8 series M isn't half bad though

snippet.textDisplay:
My opinion on what is keeping the foot on the break:
1) Ignoring Android Auto;
2) Styling not following function - their kidney grills are getting larger while the industry technological need has reduced, eg electric cars.
3) Not enough styling differentiation between models, and ugly application /translation to X coupe models.
4) Touting tech like Hydrogen fuel cells for decades but never implementing, leaving the impression of not really being capable.
snippet.textOriginal:
My opinion on what is keeping the foot on the break:
1) Ignoring Android Auto;
2) Styling not following function - their kidney grills are getting larger while the industry technological need has reduced, eg electric cars.
3) Not enough styling differentiation between models, and ugly application /translation to   X coupe models.
4) Touting tech like Hydrogen fuel cells for decades but never implementing, leaving the impression of not really being capable.

snippet.textDisplay: The reason BMW became so huge and desirable is because the company had a mission statement to build the ultimate driving machine and they delivered decade after decade. There was a point in the late 2000’s and early 2010’s that it seemed as if the brand no longer cared about that and only wanted to increase sales and appeal to bigger markets. Though somewhat successful, everybody drives a bmw now, not just purists and wealthy elitists, it has cost the brand it’s reputation and original appeal. I hope the brand goes back to making truly driver focused cars again. I used to be a huge fan but I no longer desire to buy a new BMW these days.
snippet.textOriginal: The reason BMW became so huge and desirable is because the company had a mission statement to build the ultimate driving machine and they delivered decade after decade. There was a point in the late 2000’s and early 2010’s that it seemed as if the brand no longer cared about that and only wanted to increase sales and appeal to bigger markets. Though somewhat successful, everybody drives a bmw now, not just purists and wealthy elitists, it has cost the brand it’s reputation and original appeal. I hope the brand goes back to making truly driver focused cars again. I used to be a huge fan but I no longer desire to buy a new BMW these days.

snippet.textDisplay: Rented a 2020 330i for a few days. Wasn't impressed for the money they want for these.  Interior seemed cheapy, and had exposed screws for the seats into the floor boards and also had door rattles.   The digital instrumentation is distracting and hard to read at a quick glance. Nobody asked for gauges that look like a crab extending its claws.  Also turning everything into a 4cyl turbo with start/stop means less about driving experience and just trying to get more MPGs.
snippet.textOriginal: Rented a 2020 330i for a few days. Wasn't impressed for the money they want for these.  Interior seemed cheapy, and had exposed screws for the seats into the floor boards and also had door rattles.   The digital instrumentation is distracting and hard to read at a quick glance. Nobody asked for gauges that look like a crab extending its claws.  Also turning everything into a 4cyl turbo with start/stop means less about driving experience and just trying to get more MPGs.

snippet.textDisplay: BMW has lost track of their customer base by creating cheaper, uglier, less reliable products. The late 90’s was peak BMW; ever since, they’ve been in a downward trajectory by not maintaining the core values (polished engineering, simple ergonomics, clean and unfettered looks) that made people fall in love with their vehicles in the first place.
snippet.textOriginal: BMW has lost track of their customer base by creating cheaper, uglier, less reliable products. The late 90’s was peak BMW; ever since, they’ve been in a downward trajectory by not maintaining the core values (polished engineering, simple ergonomics, clean and unfettered looks) that made people fall in love with their vehicles in the first place.

snippet.textDisplay:
2020 - BMW Reclaims Luxury Sales Crown in the US after 4-year hiatus
https://www.bmwblog.com/2020/01/04/bmw-gets-back-ahead-of-mercedes-benz-in-us-sales/
For decades, BMW has been building gigantic hidden reserves outside off the balance sheet (probably for tax reasons [corporate tax and inheritance tax Quandt / Klatten]). BMW's accounting seems to be very conservative. In Germany and Munich, real estate prices have risen sharply for years. "BMW is one of the largest landowners in the north of Munich." In the balance, however, all land and real estate of BMW are still at the decades-old production costs. Price appreciation in real estate is an important factor. Munich is clearly one of the most expensive areas in Germany BMW operates 30 production and assembly plants in 14 countries. The book value does not contain the huge hidden reserves. For example, 50% of the share in the highly profitable Chinese BBA alone is worth over 7.2 billion. Most people don't know these features of german accounting that partly remains even after adoption of IFRS. Brand value - BMW improved from 13th to 11th place with $ 40.4 billion plus "Mini" plus "Rolls-Royce". Already the book values are calculated by balancing experts 2019 to over 94 euros (2021: 101 euros). It was and is always only a matter of time for the book values to prevail. And they are fully disjunkt to the hidden reserves. Over the last years BMW has been the most profitable caremarker worldwide. X7 is only the beginning. Wait for the new 2020/2021-Technologies BMW has secretlly developed.
(1) BMW will provide 13 Top BEV in 2023 (press release 2019)
(2) BMW are already biggest German seller of electric with their multiple PHEV, with 20% market share (I.e., more than their ICE share)
(3) BMW is selling the most advanced, efficient and exhaust-optimized ICE in Germany (Gas and Diesel) available in classes of engine power (136 up to 625 hp)
(4) Some BMW designs are already prepared for H2 fuel cells
(1) - (4) can be manufactured on the same production lines just in time according to customer requirements. This is a huge USP.
And BMW is building up significant additional production facilities to over 3 Million cars per year.
There might be huge catching up potential for BMWs market capitalization on the stock market?

snippet.textDisplay: Boils down to reliability.  YouTube videos of broken down hard to repair BMW’s rivals Range Rovers for the same reason.  A couple popular YouTube stars have made BMWs literally running jokes over their lack of reliability and some models being the most hated models in the automotive world.  I personally got rid of a pretty decent 3 series just over 90k miles because of BMWs reputation of rapid degradation of reliability over the 100k mile mark.

snippet.textDisplay: The current 330i has a 4-cylinder turbo engine an no manual gearbox, ultimate driving machine my ass. In comparison the E90 330i with six cylinder and manual was a sublime everyday sports car which just happened to seat 4 comfortably and 5 if needed. Then the current M5 weighs about 4500 lbs with driver,  it may be fast but it's a bloody tank and the feeling is all wrong. It has more in common with a big Bentley GT than the M5 cars of old. Then Audi went and made the R8, the car that arguably BMW should have made and used the M1 badge for. The list goes on. I don't blame BMW for making cars like the 2-series or X3 really, if they sell then make them. Sure. But BMW have messed up some of their most iconic cars and thereby lost touch with its old core audience. Even when they try to make something "hardcore" like the M4 CS it comes across as more of a German teenagers aftermarket tuning exercise than an actual M car by people who care about driving. I mean in the M4 CS they replaced the doorhandle with a strap but left the door lever, armrest and heavy electric seats.. just a perfect example of how confused and unfocused BMW is today.

snippet.textDisplay: Mercedes only beat BMW in Europe because it has embraced the very cheap end of the market in conjunction with Renault powertrains. They have gone for the lower end of the market an have lost the 'quality' cache, starting with massive cost cutting back at the turn of the century. BMW, despite also embracing the mass market, continue to have a premium reputation and sell for a reasonable premium price even at the lower end.

snippet.textDisplay:
Some reference here: yes Mercedes is beating BMW in pure volume as Mercedes has moved to cheaper vehicles that can sell to even the lower middle class (C class) and having a massive range to sell.

They complain about BMW not innovating into the sport branding, while also complaining they dont focus on electric. 0-60 isnt sport, and physics wont let's heavy batteries handle well. They have to pick a lane, just as Aston Martin and porche still offer 3 pedal manuals because of those people who buy. Sure those 2 have electric cars, but that's not their focus.

This comes down to many analysts wanting different things for the industry as a whole, while using BMW falling in volume to Mercedes as justification without looking into how Mercedes gets there. Focus on what makes a single manufacturer important, and they can carve out their own niche in the market. This SUV trend grows and shrinks with economic growth and decline, and premium electric will hurt possibly even worse but that is yet to be seen.

I'm not a fan boy of any of these companies (I own a lotus and miata, so fairly disconnected from all of it) but some of these issues in the research are glaring. These aren't BMW analysts, they are market analysts, so its difficult to take them seriously when they say "bmw needs to differentiate themselves" and "they should follow where the market is going" in the same sentence...
snippet.textOriginal:
Some reference here: yes Mercedes is beating BMW in pure volume as Mercedes has moved to cheaper vehicles that can sell to even the lower middle class (C class) and having a massive range to sell. 

They complain about BMW not innovating into the sport branding, while also complaining they dont focus on electric. 0-60 isnt sport, and physics wont let's heavy batteries handle well. They have to pick a lane, just as Aston Martin and porche still offer 3 pedal manuals because of those people who buy. Sure those 2 have electric cars, but that's not their focus. 

This comes down to many analysts wanting different things for the industry as a whole, while using BMW falling in volume to Mercedes as justification without looking into how Mercedes gets there. Focus on what makes a single manufacturer important, and they can carve out their own niche in the market. This SUV trend grows and shrinks with economic growth and decline, and premium electric will hurt possibly even worse but that is yet to be seen.

I'm not a fan boy of any of these companies (I own a lotus and miata, so fairly disconnected from all of it) but some of these issues in the research are glaring. These aren't BMW analysts, they are market analysts, so its difficult to take them seriously when they say "bmw needs to differentiate themselves" and "they should follow where the market is going" in the same sentence...

snippet.textDisplay:
The famous German and especially BMW technical capabilities, precision, competence is partly (heavily) gone.
Having worked with germans and for german companies for more than 10 years I can state that.
Having moreover a BMW M6 since 15 years I know how many design defects are there, how much planned obsolescence was made by design that I had to fix it myself.
Last but not least, the BMW service is normally costing 4 times what should/could be, and technicians and managers are normally very unfriendly or...foxy. That is perceived worldwide so that indeed BMW dealers are called "stealers".
Compared to 4 other cars (not BMW) I had with only minor issues till 260000km, this BMW is not worth the initial and following cost at all.
snippet.textOriginal:

Having moreover a BMW M6 since 15 years I know how many design defects are there, how much planned obsolescence was made by design that I had to fix it myself. 
Last but not least, the BMW service is normally costing 4 times what should/could be, and technicians and managers are normally very unfriendly or...foxy. That is perceived worldwide so that indeed BMW dealers are called "stealers".
Compared to 4 other cars (not BMW) I had with only minor issues till 260000km, this BMW is not worth the initial and following cost at all.

snippet.textDisplay:
We live in a world were we can easily understand the concept of market segments and as much as an automaker will try to stretch into segments outside of their regular consumer base to generate profit that doesn't mean their identity has changed. BMW IS and WILL CONTINUE to be the brand that delivers the best balance between luxury, technology and insane power making it the ultimate driving machine, period.

Sales figures also don't mean a thing when compared to companies like Mercedez who focus solely on luxury and feel numb and frigile when driving. It's like comparing Ducati to Harley Davidson, please, don't make me laugh.

You know who outsales the crap out of them both, ANY JAPANESE BRAND.

snippet.textDisplay: This report sounds like it was put together by a high schooler trying to get a word count for an essay and only looked at one article to form the entire argument. If BMW and it’s analysts just looked at the comments on here there wouldn’t be a need for market research to find out what’s happening to their brand. We want reliability and if every model is plagued by an interior that falls apart, an engine that is sure to blow if you don’t replace a bearing, or a subframe that’s rips apart then we’re sure to change brands. To make it worse they always fight liability. If it sounds like I’m a little bitter then they have to ask why loyal customers like myself feel like this and how to correct that before making their grills larger.

snippet.textDisplay: BMW’s innovative success was producing high performance internal combustion engines in the 20th Century. The 21st Century has quickly shown that electric motors are the future in terms of fuel efficiency, emissions and performance. BMW’s golden goose is rapidly becoming obsolete. Hitching your (electric) wagon to an antiquated ICE engine technology with their Plug-In Hybrid strategy exemplifies how the BMW Group is unable to cut their losses and truly innovate. They will die a slow and painful death...
snippet.textOriginal: BMW’s innovative success was producing high performance internal combustion engines in the 20th Century. The 21st Century has quickly shown that electric motors are the future in terms of fuel efficiency, emissions and performance. BMW’s golden goose is rapidly becoming obsolete. Hitching your (electric) wagon to an antiquated ICE engine technology with their Plug-In Hybrid strategy exemplifies how the BMW Group is unable to cut their losses and truly innovate. They will die a slow and painful death...
